articles.description: Are you more likely to die on your birthday? Yes.
articles.title: Are you more likely to die on your birthday?

articles.description: We try to predict the price and quality of a bottle of wine based on the animal on the label.
articles.title: The Pour-igin of Species

articles.author: Charlie Wood
articles.description:
The physicist Sidney Nagel delights in solving mysteries of the universe that are hiding in plain sight.            
The post Finding Beauty and Truth in Mundane Occurrences first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Finding Beauty and Truth in Mundane Occurrences

articles.author: Ajdina Halilovic
articles.description:
How do memories last a lifetime when the molecules that form them turn over within days, weeks or months? An interaction between two proteins points to a molecular basis for memory.            
The post The Molecular Bond That Helps Secure Your Memories first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: The Molecular Bond That Helps Secure Your Memories

articles.author: Erica Klarreich
articles.description:
A new proof represents the culmination of a 65-year-old story about anomalous shapes in special dimensions.            
The post Dimension 126 Contains Strangely Twisted Shapes, Mathematicians Prove first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Dimension 126 Contains Strangely Twisted Shapes, Mathematicians Prove

articles.author: Janna Levin and Steven Strogatz
articles.description:
AI may sound like a human, but that doesn’t mean that AI learns like a human. In this episode, Ellie Pavlick explains why understanding how LLMs can process language could unlock deeper insights into both AI and the human mind.            
The post Will AI Ever Understand Language Like Humans? first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Will AI Ever Understand Language Like Humans?

articles.author: Michael Moyer, Ben Brubaker, John Pavlus, Mark Belan, Jordana Cepelewicz, Yasemin Saplakoglu, Gregory Barber, Elise Cutts and Emily Buder
articles.description:
An exploration of how artificial intelligence is changing what it means to do science and math, and what it means to be a scientist.            
The post Science, Promise and Peril in the Age of AI first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Science, Promise and Peril in the Age of AI

articles.description: Building a high-speed rail between Los Angeles and San Francisco was never going to be easy — but the critics who write it off are missing the real source of the project’s struggles.
articles.title: Reports of the Death of  California High-Speed Rail Have Been Greatly Exaggerated

articles.description: A conversation about the factors that might slow down the pace of AI development, what could happen next, and whether we’ll be able to see it coming.
articles.title: Does AI Progress Have a Speed Limit?

articles.description: Kelsey Piper and Jasmine Sun talk about microschools, whether localism is the enemy of Abundance, and why Chinese bureaucrats are like Growth PMs.
articles.title: Does Abundance Start at Home?

articles.author: Becky Ferreira
articles.description: The Yangtze finless porpoise is near extinction in the wild, but glimpses of its heyday can be found in centuries of Chinese poetry.
articles.title: Ancient Poems Record the Decline of a Special Porpoise

articles.description: Ricardo Prada Vásquez was not on a government list of people sent to a mega prison in El Salvador. But hacked data shows he was booked on a flight to the country.
articles.title: Man ‘Disappeared’ by ICE Was on El Salvador Flight Manifest, Hacked Data Shows

articles.description: Meta previously lost its shit at 404 Media when we reported that someone had paired facial recognition tech with the company's smart glasses. Now Meta is building the invasive technology itself.
articles.title: Well, Well, Well: Meta to Add Facial Recognition To Glasses After All

articles.description: Hackers say they have obtained what they say are passenger lists for GlobalX flights from January to this month. The data appears to include people who have been deported.
articles.title: GlobalX, Airline for Trump’s Deportations, Hacked

articles.author: Emanuel Maiberg
articles.description: An open AI video generation model that was released last month is now being used by thousands of people to generate nonconsensual sexual videos of real people.
articles.title: 100,000 People Are Using a Telegram Bot That Makes AI Cumshot Videos of Anyone
